title: TomPegden published Indian summer hits Dunelm sales
text:
Indian summer hits Dunelm sales By TomPegden | Posted: October 06, 2016 0 COMMENTS SHARES Chief executive John Browett: "Looking forward to a stronger second quarter" Indian summer hits Dunelm sales X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
The Indian summer hit sales at county homeware chain Dunelm – although home deliveries continue to grow. 
Posting its first post-Brexit figures, the Syston-based business said revenues fell 1.8 per cent to just under £199 million in the 13 weeks to October 1. 
Like-for-like store sales – which don't include growth created by new shops or online sales – were down more than 5 per cent. 
The business said: "As expected, unusually warm weather had a dampening effect on store footfall. 
"We did however, continue to see good growth in the online business, including a 17.9 per cent increase in home delivery sales. 
"Overall, we believe that we are continuing to outperform the homewares market as a whole." 
The home furnishing retailer, which sells everything from bedding to curtains, furniture, beds and mattresses, now has 152 stores and is committed to 10 new stores, with four due before the end of the calendar year. 
A further 15 stores are being refitted. 
Dunelm had posted a 7.1 per cent rise in total revenues to almost £881 million in its previous full year to July 2 . 
Chief executive John Browett said: "As expected, the homewares market has fallen due to unusually warm weather and this has correspondingly impacted our store performance over the period, given the reduced footfall to our out-of-town superstores. 
"However, we have continued to focus on our value based customer proposition and are increasing our market share in homewares, whilst also seeing good growth in our online business. 
"We are looking forward to a stronger second quarter as we continue to invest in extra seasonal space, new till systems, store refits and new store openings. We should also benefit from weaker comparatives. 
"We continue to focus on our key initiatives whilst ensuring we maintain our unique offer of tremendous value for money, combined with an unrivalled range and great service." 
Russ Mould, investment director at investment company AJ Bell, said Dunelm was the FTSE 250's biggest faller today, down more than 4.6 per cent by lunchtime. 
He said: "The hot spell reduced footfall at its out-of-town superstores but the group continues to see good growth in its online business. 
"Dunelm will be looking forward to a stronger second quarter as it continues to invest in extra seasonal space, new till systems, store refits and new store openings and it should also benefit from weaker comparatives." 
Dunelm said stores which had been open longer than a year contributed £173.9 million in revenue, while home deliveries brought in £13.6 million – compared to £11.5 million in the same period last year. New stores brought in £11.2 million. 
The first quarter trading update said: "Gross margin is estimated to be broadly flat when compared to the equivalent quarter last year. 
"As yet we have not seen any material impact from adverse foreign exchange markets in relation to goods sourced directly or from third parties."
